summary: W. R. Wannall is mentioned in several FBI memoranda, primarily in the context of the Senate Select Committee (SSC) investigations into intelligence activities in the mid-1970s. He appears to be an FBI official involved in coordinating responses to the SSC's inquiries, particularly concerning CIA activities and FBI investigations, including those related to Martin Luther King Jr. and alleged Communist ties. Wannall's role involves handling sensitive information and ensuring proper coordination between the FBI and CIA during the SSC's review of intelligence operations. One document specifically mentions a memorandum from W. G. Cregar to W. R. Wannall regarding a CIA document detailing questionable activities involving both the CIA and FBI, which was under review by the SSC.
significance: W. R. Wannall's significance in the JFK context is indirect. He is mentioned in documents related to the Senate Select Committee's investigation into intelligence activities, which included inquiries into the FBI's investigation of Martin Luther King Jr. and his alleged communist ties. While the documents do not directly link Wannall to the JFK assassination, they highlight his involvement in handling sensitive information and coordinating responses to congressional inquiries related to intelligence matters during a period when the JFK assassination was also subject to scrutiny.
